text:
Who wants to join a JS challenge?
<https://www.adventofjs.com/>
I knew you would like it :wink:

Hey <@U027BLET13R> happy to connect :slightly_smiling_face:
Hope you are having great time getting ready for a holiday season :christmas_tree:
You can find me on Twitter as @OliaGozha :slightly_smiling_face:

Here’s also a CSS advent challenge in case anyone interested :christmas_tree:
<https://www.adventofcss.com/>
Never heard of this. Thanks <@U02KUKZ1MT8> for sharing. Now curious about how it works :thinking_face:
I want a system that does the opposite of this, code to design. Has anyone found a solution like that?
<@UJQNNKKHN> not yet. How would you envision this to work?
Coded components would get translated to sketch symbols. Thus you would maintain a design system in code, and designers would be able to use those components to create larger layouts in sketch

I haven't used Anima, so no idea how well it works, but the reason I learned how to code is because it gives you total control over how your design looks in a browser. In my experience using something that autogenerates code for you leaves  a lot up to interpretation.
<@UJQNNKKHN> As a designer, I’m with you on this. Being able to code really empowers designers turning them into makers.
It’s an interesting perspective to look at this as a back-and-forth process of components from code to design and vice versa

Yes... obviously anything brand new would start in sketch, but as far as maintaining a sketch library, it makes way more sense to derive a sketch library from an existing coded design system that the dev team is already putting a lot of time into perfecting, vs. the design team trying to maintain a redundant library that looks very similar to the actual design system.
I'm curious if it would save time, especially given the limitations of the HubSpot CMS
